user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ForEachObjectOfType:
```c
void OS_ForEachObjectOfType(osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t creator_id, OS_ArgCallback_t callback_ptr,
                            void *callback_arg)
{
    OS_object_iter_t    iter;
    OS_creator_filter_t filter;

    filter.creator_id    = creator_id;
    filter.user_callback = callback_ptr;
    filter.user_arg      = callback_arg;

    if (OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ForEachFilterCreator, &filter, idtype, &iter) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
        {
            OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(&iter, OS_ForEachDoCallback);
        }

        OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ForEachObjectOfType:
typedef void (*OS_ArgCallback_t)(osal_id_t object_id, void *arg)
...
typedef struct
{
    osal_id_t        creator_id;
    OS_ArgCallback_t user_callback;
    void *           user_arg;
} OS_creator_filter_t
...
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t matchfunc, void *matcharg, osal_objtype_t objtype,
                              OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    iter->match = matchfunc;
    iter->arg   = matcharg;
    iter->limit = OS_GetMaxForObjectType(objtype);
    iter->base  = &OS_common_table[OS_GetBaseForObjectType(objtype)];

    return OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, objtype, &iter->token);
}
...
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(OS_object_iter_t *iter, int32 (*func)(osal_id_t, void *))
{
    int32 status;

    /*
     * This needs to temporarily unlock the global,
     * call the handler function, then re-lock.
     */
    OS_Unlock_Global(&iter->token);
    status = func(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(&iter->token), iter->arg);
    OS_Lock_Global(&iter->token);

    return status;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(&iter->token);
}
...
bool OS_ForEachFilterCreator(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    OS_creator_filter_t *filter = ref;

    /*
     * Check if the obj_id is both valid and matches
     * the specified creator_id
     */
    return (OS_ObjectIdIsValid(obj->active_id) && (OS_ObjectIdEqual(filter->creator_id, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY) ||
                                                   OS_ObjectIdEqual(obj->creator, filter->creator_id)));
}
...
int32 OS_ForEachDoCallback(osal_id_t obj_id, void *ref)
{
    OS_creator_filter_t *filter = ref;

    /* Just invoke the user callback */
    filter->user_callback(obj_id, filter->user_arg);
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I flagged all code fragments where context/callback pointers are declared or passed as plain void * (or stored in non-const void * fields). These are the locations most likely to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 because the pointed-to data appears to be treated read-only within these functions and could often be const-qualified. Other code fragments were not flagged because they either already use const for the pointed-to type (for example the token and obj parameters in the match function are const-qualified), or they are pointers that are clearly intended for modification (e.g., iter->base, iter->token, or pointers into the object table) and therefore cannot be const-qualified without changing the intended semantics. Additionally, API-level callback types (user callbacks and iterator function signatures) constrain whether certain pointer parameters can be changed to const without an API change; where that API already requires non-const pointers for use by external callers, those usages were not separately flagged as they reflect intentional design choices.
